name: Isaak Bacharach
content:
Isaak Bacharach (2 December 1854  – 22 September 1942) was a German mathematics professor in Erlangen who proved the Cayley–Bacharach theorem on intersections of cubic curves.[1][2]
 He was murdered at the Theresienstadt concentration camp during the Holocaust.[3]

raw:
German mathematician
For the American politician, see Isaac Bacharach.


Isaak BacharachBorn(1854-12-02)December 2, 1854Seligenstadt, Hesse, German ConfederationDiedSeptember 22, 1942(1942-09-22) (aged 87)Theresienstadt concentration camp, Protectorate of Bohemia and MoraviaNationalityGermanAlma materUniversity of Erlangen-NurembergKnown forCayley–Bacharach theoremScientific careerFieldsMathematicsThesisÜber Schnittpunktsysteme algebraischer Curven (1881)

Isaak Bacharach (2 December 1854  – 22 September 1942) was a German mathematics professor in Erlangen who proved the Cayley–Bacharach theorem on intersections of cubic curves.[1][2]
He was murdered at the Theresienstadt concentration camp during the Holocaust.[3]

References[edit]


^ Bacharach, I. (1886), "Ueber den Cayley'schen Schnittpunktsatz" (PDF), Mathematische Annalen, Berlin and Heidelberg: Springer, 26: 275–299, doi:10.1007/BF01444338, ISSN 0025-5831

^ Eisenbud, David; Green, Mark; Harris, Joe (1996). "Cayley-Bacharach theorems and conjectures" (PDF). Bulletin of the AMS. 33: 295–324.

^ "Bacharach Isaak: Death Certificate, Ghetto Terezín". Holocaust.cz. Archived from the original on 28 November 2012.
